      80             : 
      81             : /** \rst
      82             :     A call policy which places one or more guard variables (``Ts...``) around the function call.
      83             : 
      84             :     For example, this definition:
      85             : 
      86             :     .. code-block:: cpp
      87             : 
      88             :         m.def("foo", foo, py::call_guard<T>());
      89             : 
      90             :     is equivalent to the following pseudocode:
      91             : 
      92             :     .. code-block:: cpp
      93             : 
      94             :         m.def("foo", [](args...) {
      95             :             T scope_guard;
      96             :             return foo(args...); // forwarded arguments
      97             :         });
      98             :  \endrst */
      99             : template <typename... Ts> struct call_guard;
     100             : 
     101             : template <> struct call_guard<> { using type = detail::void_type; };

     105             :     static_assert(std::is_default_constructible<T>::value,
     106             :                   "The guard type must be default constructible");
     107             : 
     108             :     using type = T;

     503             :  * otherwise
     504             :  */

     536             : template <typename T>
     537             : using is_call_guard = is_instantiation<call_guard, T>;

     546             :           size_t self  = constexpr_sum(std::is_same<is_method, Extra>::value...)>
